Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2008 10:38AM yellowtownhouse wrote: Hi All, Well I had my simulation Thursday and it was h***! On the table 50 minutes in "the position."  Was told I could not have a break for my arms as that would mean starting all over. During my time on the table I could hear the techs paging my oncologist over and over and over to come to the simulation room.  I'm not sure if he ever showed up.  I did finally hear the tech page for a doesimitrist to call or come to the simulation room.  Somebody tell me what that was all about.  I know what I think, but want to know what you all think.   I was in so much pain at the finish that I cried for 30 minutes before I could drive my car.  I was also told not to even consider using anything on my chest...just to leave it alone.  She said, "you won't need anything until at least the end of three weeks."  I have 7 round pieces of tape over all of my marks.  I was told that if the time comes to use a lotion that I was to stay 2 inches away from all the tape circles.  Now... they are scattered all over my left chest wall with one on the right side.  How could I possibly use anything and stay 2 inches away from all of the marks????  Help you all....I'm kind of freaking about this. Had my first actual tx yesterday (Friday).  Again, a long time on the table because they take a lot of pictures first and then treat.  The tech said they would repeat the picture taking every 7-10 days.  Total time in the position yesterday, 35 minutes. Diane...If I had 2 busy children I wouldn't even consider working 32 hours.  I think you're very smart to ease back into the work place and still give yourself time for family.  I guess I will have to wait and see what my fatigue level is to really determine if I'll be able to continue my hours.  Kajo....So glad your surgeon called and relieved your mind!  Isn't it awful the places our minds carry us to when we're in panic mode?  Only someone who has had our experiences would truly understand that feeling.  My best to everyone, June PS...Hey DeAnn...glad to see an old 'neighbor.'  :)
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2008 05:54PM yellowtownhouse wrote: Hi to All, Thought I'd share where I am in this radiation process.  I had 8 txs of chemo/ 2 surgeries (12/18 and 1/8) and have had my consult and planning session.  Thursday is my simulation and Friday 2/1, I actually begin tx.  It's lovely to have other "sisters" to share with as we all begin another phase of tx.  I'm very glad to have found you all to share with.  I used the chemo support site and don't know what I would have done without the support I received from my chemo "sisters".  I'm sure that we will all be better from having each other during this time.  I work 32 hrs a week and am also wondering what the fatique level will be.  I was able to schedule a 4pm appt. daily which will enable me to work most of the day/ go for rads/ and then fall in bed if I need to.  Here's hoping NONE of us need to. I was also told by my Rad. Onc. that smaller, thinner chested woman don't seem to have as much skin reaction.  I am not large chested but without my bra I suddenly have 3 navels!!!!  Anybody know what I mean?  :>   There is no way possible I could go without a bra and work!  Give me a break please!  I'm looking forward to new companions on yet another journey for all of us.  I'll post again after Friday. Best to all...... June

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2008 06:10PM yellowtownhouse wrote: Hey Everyone, I am now a veteran of rad txs with 3 under my belt!  :) I'm scheduled for a six week course.  The arm pain is a tad better and of course 10 minutes vs. any additional minutes on those tables  is a God send.  I'm still very torn regarding the skin issue  and lotions.  If you remember my onc and the techs were just adament about NOT using anything until they told me to!  I'm in the medical profession and usually try to weigh any advice againest what I think is best for me.  I'm also a bit of a rebel;  so  if you're going to give me that strong of a directive.....then by gosh you HAD better be right!  AHHHH.... decisions...decisions. KarenX......Just wanted to comment on your comment regarding your company that can't accomodate a reduced work schedule.  Are you in the states?  If so the American Disabilities Act covers you in the workplace.  It clearly states that cancer and cancer treatment is a disability and your employer must make accomodations for you.  Google their site and read more if you're interested.  It gives clear examples of the type of accomodations that are considered normal and justified.  I'm not trying to tell you to start a war with your employer but if you're an American citizen you do have some rights.  Good Luck to you. My best to all and lets keep writing. June
